mnemonic: ONZE sounds like 'owns' - he OWNS eleven things
grammar_notes: Numbers 11-15 all end in '-ze'. They're irregular - memorize them.
cultural_note: Portugal uses European spelling: dezasseis not dezesseis (Brazilian).

mnemonic: DOZE rhymes with 'pose' - a dozen roses in a pose
cultural_note: 'Uma dúzia' (a dozen) is commonly used for eggs and pastéis de nata!

mnemonic: TREZE sounds like 'tray' - 13 things on a TRAY
grammar_notes: Thirteen - considered unlucky in some cultures.
cultural_note: In Portugal the unlucky number is actually Friday 13th just like English-speaking countries.

mnemonic: CaTORZE = CAT + TORSO = 14 cats showing torsos
grammar_notes: Both 'catorze' and 'quatorze' are correct in Portugal.
cultural_note: Both spellings accepted - 'catorze' more common in European Portuguese.

mnemonic: QUINZE sounds like 'KEEN' - keen on 15 things!
grammar_notes: The 'qu' sounds like 'k' in Portuguese numbers.
cultural_note: 'Daqui a quinze dias' (in two weeks) is very common in Portuguese.

mnemonic: DEZA-SEIS = DEZ + SEIS (10+6) - math in Portuguese!
cultural_note: European Portuguese: dezasseis. Brazilian Portuguese: dezesseis.

mnemonic: DEZA-SETE = DEZ + SETE (10+7) - count it out!
cultural_note: In Portugal if someone says 'às dezassete' they mean 5 PM (17:00 in 24h time).
18 is the age of majority in Portugal - when you can vote and drink legally.
Portuguese often round up - 'quase vinte' (almost twenty) might mean 18 or 19!

mnemonic: VINTE sounds like 'VEENT' - a VENT has 20 slats!
grammar_notes: Base number for twenties. 21 = vinte e um etc.
cultural_note: 'Vinte euros' is the most common banknote used in Portugal.
tip: The base for twenties - like 'veent' plus 'uh'
